intro: Chasmanthera columba, commonly known as the blue-eyed grass, is a flowering plant native to the eastern United States. It belongs to the family Xanthorrhoeaceae and is characterized by its delicate, grass-like leaves and showy, blue or violet flowers. The plant typically grows in moist, woodland habitats and thrives in partial to full shade. Its small, tubular flowers are pollinated by bees and other insects, contributing to its ecological importance. Chasmanthera columba is often found in wetlands and along stream banks, where it plays a role in stabilizing soil and supporting local biodiversity.
